thesis.description: In spite of the early and brilliant observations of clinical pathologists, notably Rokitansky, who first called attention to the association of brain damage and pathological changes in the stomach, suggesting a neurogenic basis for ulcer formation, this concept was for many decades overshadowed by the views of Virchow and his followers who held that peptic ulcer was essentially a local disease. Although the neurogenic concept was later supported by both experimental and clinical studies, it was not until the publication of Gushing*s Balfour Lecture, relating peptic ulcer to disturbances in the interbrain, that the interest in this aspect of ulcer formation was revived.[...]
thesis.creator: Wener, J.
thesis.subject: Physiology.
thesis.title: The neuro-humeral aspects of ulcer formation.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Although acetic acid has been found to be produced by brain tissue, it has also been found to be metabolically inert when added to brain slices and suspensions. That brain tissue, which carries on the synthesis of acetylcholine as a phase of its functional activity, can have no use for added acetate, was thought to be an interesting paradox. Carbohydrate is the main, if not the only, source of metabolic energy in brain tissue, and the acetate formed by brain tissue preparations is apparently derived from intermediary products of carbohydrate metabolism. [...]
thesis.creator: Webb, J.L.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: The formation of acetate in brain tissue suspensions.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The basis of much biological experimentation is to be found in human disease processes. It is probably generally true that the ultimate objective of such experimentation is the advancement of the knowledge of a human disease. This is indeed true of the work to be presented here. In order that proper orientation be preserved, a preliminary discussion will center upon those aspects of the human disease corresponding most closely to the affection produced experimentally in this work.[...]
thesis.creator: Waugh, D.
thesis.subject: Pathology.
thesis.title: A study of renal lesions produced in rabbits by heterologous plasma protein administration.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A cold cathode ion source which possesses to a high degree the reciuirements for a synchrocyclotron proton source has been developed. IWo variations, one of electrode configuration and one of mode of Operation, each produce currents sufficiently high to be of value either in steady or In pnlsed Operation. The maximum consistently obtained total ion Output currents in the cyclotron field (16,000 oersteds) were: [...]
thesis.creator: Warren, F. G. Ross.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: A cold cathode proton source for the synchrocyclotron.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: During the last thirty years there has developed a trend of investigation designed to ascertain the actual material necessary for the growth of various micro-organisms. Such research was initiated because of the desire to culture bacteria in media of known chemical composition. Originally culture media were complex and designed to provide nutrients such as were found by organisms in their natural environment, but the discovery of bacteria which require special conditions for cultivation attracted attention to the possibility of nutritional deficiency even in complex mediaj therefore knowledge was lacking on the behavior of organisms whose nutrient requirements were most exacting. [...]
thesis.creator: Wallace, R.H.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Bacteriology.
thesis.title: The nutritional requirements of soil bacteria as influenced by the growth of various crop plants.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: [...] Expressions are now available for the overall rate of polymerization and the average degree of polymerization which can be compared directly with experimental data. However, these are not sufficient to determine unambiguously the individual rate constants of the different elementary steps, having only two equations and at least three unknowns. Other expressions are required which combine these same unknowns with directly measurable quantities. One of these is the distribution function of the polymer formed after different lengths of time under various experimental conditions. Attempts have been made in this direction by Ginell and Simfca (10) and Eyring et al (8).[...]
thesis.creator: Walker, Jessie Mary.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The kinetics of copolymerization of butadiene and styrene in homogeneous solutions.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: An experimental and theoretical examination has been made of the gamma-radiation inside and in the vicinity of extended radioactive sources. Initial ionisation experiments are described in which the "air-wall" chamber method is used to study the gamma-radiation arising from extended sources composed of radio-cobalt (Co60) in aqueous solutions* Coincidence counting measurements are described for determining the absolute radioactive content of a sample Coou source. An approximate theoretical analysis is presented for multiply-scattered gamma-rays for a point source and an extended source* Previous theoretical predictions on the relationship between the roentgen and absolute energy units have been confirmed experimentally for the gamma-rays from Co60. Experimental evidence is presented that an "air-wall" ionisation chamber is suitable for the measurement of garama-radiation, expressed in roentgens or in absolute energy units, inside an extended radioactive body. The effective self-absorption coefficient for aqueous Co60 spherical sources has been deduced both experimentally and theoretically to be given by the Klein-Nishina cross-section for true energy absorption from the primary gamma-rays. [...]
thesis.creator: Voyvodic, Louis.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Intensity and energy absorption studies on extended gamma-ray sources.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: During the last decade, increasing interest has been shown in the isolation of large quantities of pure amino acids from proteins, for nutritional and medicinal therapy, and for other pure and applied research problems. Much progress has been made in improving methods of fractionation of protein hydrolysates, but most methods are still unsatisfactory. Fairly good methods have been devis for the isolation of basic and acidic amino acids, but the neutral amino acids are considerably more difficult to separate. [...]
thesis.creator: Van Horn, William Fitch.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
thesis.title: Fractionation of protein hydrolysates.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Initial observations on the microwave absorption spectrum of methylene chloride have been made with a double modulation spectrometer. A total of twenty-eight lines has been found in the wave-length region round 1.25 cm. Twelve of these are contained in four closely spaced triplets. This spectrum is consistent wiiih the rotational spectrum calculated from the rigid asymmetric top model of the molecule and a tentative assignment of transitions is made. affective rotational constants and moments of inertia are obtained from the observed results. The hyperfine structure observed is thought to arise from the chlorine nuclear quadrupole moments but no attempt is made to correlate this with theory. [...]
thesis.creator: Turner, Terry Earle.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: The microwave absorption of methylene chloride.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Epilepsy has been defined as a tendency to recurring epileptic seizures, which areproduced by excessive neuronal discharge with the nervous system. It is not strictly a disease but a symptom of disease (Penfield and Erickson, 1941). Pathologically and anatomically the eiplepsies differ widely byt are joined by the common physiological mechanism manifested by the seizure. Clinically two types have been distinguished, the symptomatic in which some pathological cause such as cerebral tumar can be demostrated, and the Idiopathic (essential or cryptogenic) in which no cause can be found (Penfield and Erickson, 1941). It is this syndrome or disease entity which has been one of the great problems of medical science and civilization. [...]
thesis.creator: Tower, Donald B.
thesis.subject: Neurology & Neurosurgery.
thesis.title: Acetylcholine and neuronal activity in craniocerebral trauma and epilepsy.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The studies reported in this thesis were undertaken with the principal intent of attempting to evaluate the role of insulin and of the blood sugar level on hydropic degeneration of the islets of Langerhans of rabbits made diabetic by injection of alloxan. It was also hoped that an approach might be made to determining the nature of the hydropic cell. A more remote expectation was that permanent cure or alleviation of the diabetic state might be attained by therapeutic restoration of the islet cells to normal morphological appearance.
thesis.creator: Toreson, W. E.
thesis.subject: Pathology.
thesis.title: The influence of insulin and of blood sugar level on hydropic degeneration of the islets of Langerhans in alloxan diabetes.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Fluid flow has been measured through almost every type of porous material. A considerable portion of these permeability studies has been directed towards the flow of gases through a bed of charcoal grains. The interest in gas flow through charcoal arises from the ability of charcoal to separate one gas from another, and this property has been widely applied both in chemical warfare and industry. It is of fundamental importance to the knowledge of gas flow through a bed of charcoal grains to understand the process by which the sorbable gas is carried into the interior of the charcoal grain. [...]
thesis.creator: Tomlinson, Richard Howden.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The flow of gases and vapours through absorbing porous media.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It was felt that a bridge was missing from the family of bridges in the literature dealing with the comparison of capacitance, mutual inductance and/or self inductance. This new bridge would bear a similar relationship to Maxwell Abridge that the Heydweiller did to the Owen. Reference to Appendix I will show these relationships. To keep the study to reasonably comprehensive limits particular attention is to be paid to the comparison of the new bridge with Maxwell's bridge. Frequently the effects of quadrature components of bridge units on the final balance conditions are glossed over in the study of simple bridges in elementary work. These components do not always affect, appreciably, the results for moderately accurate work.[...]
thesis.creator: Thurston, Arthur Munro.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: A new bridge for comparing capacitance, mutual inductance and self inductance.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Tne first, fundamental question asked of the work of an artist is this one -- does he find and collect and comminicate "reality"? And in the quality and sureness of his expressed insight lies his success or failure as an artist. The novel, the most independent, most elastic, most prodigious of literary forms, attains its object in the communication of a full, intense, complex awareness or vision of human life. "II faudrait reconnaitre que l'art du roman est, avant tout, une transpos ition du reel et non une reproduction du reel", states Franeois Mauriac.
thesis.creator: Tansey, Charlotte Hunter.
thesis.subject: Stein, Gertrude, 1874-1946.
thesis.title: Human relations in the fiction of Gertrude Stein.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The study of the clay colloids of soils was initiated by Schloesing (46), who in 1870-74, separated, what he termed colloidal clay from French soils. He accomplished this by triturating the soil in the presence of water, decanting the supernatant and then permitting the clay particles to settle out. The material which remained in suspension after 24 hours settling, he designated clay colloid. It comprised 1.5$ of the weight of the whole soil and was thought by Schloesing to be amorphous in nature.[...]
thesis.creator: Talvenheimo, Gerhardt.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
thesis.title: An investigation of the clay fraction of the Ste. Rosalie soil.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Streptomycin was discovered by Schatz, Bugie ana Waksman (1944) in their search for an antibiotic capable of action against grsm-negative bacteria. Since that time, so varied and numerous have been the reports to appear on laboiatory and clinical research on the antibiotic, that a comprehensive survey of the literature has proven to be beyond the scope of this review. Therefore, only those publications having direct bearing upon the problem of the mechanisms of bacterial resistance to streptomycin have here been examined. Brief mention, however, has been made of those surveys in which information on other aspects of the literature on streptomycin was thoroughly reviewed.[...]
thesis.creator: Streitfeld, M.M.
thesis.subject: Pathology.
thesis.title: Studies on the development of resistance to streptomycin by Staphylococcus Pyogenes.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A wet method for the determination of carbon was devised and used to show that total carbon, in a cellulose culture supporting Vibrio perimastix, reached a maximum on the fourth day of incubation at 30Â° C. The total amino nitrogen content showed a corresponding maximum on the fourth day, suggesting that carbon dioxide assimilation and amino nitrogen formation were linked. Added glutamate supported normal growth in the absence of carbon dioxide, effecting at least a partial substitution for the assimilated gas. Preliminary studies indicated that a pentose-like substance was synthesized during cellulose decomposition and that a fluorescing substance other than riboflavin was produced.
thesis.creator: Stranks, Donald Winfield.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Bacteriology.
thesis.title: Studies on carbon dioxide assimilation by vibrio perimastrix.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In spite of almost half a century of study the exact mechanism regulating the blood sugar level of animals has not been finally and satisfactorily elucidated. Modern theory, while perfectly adequate for all ordinary occasions, shows weaknesses when called on to explain certain pathological conditions, in particular diabetes mellitus. It is true that the present concepts can be twisted and modified to conform to the Procrustean bed of these abnormalities, but the result is not altogether satisfying and there remain one or two hard facts that are resistant to explanation.[...]
thesis.creator: Stewart, R.D.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Search for pancreatic alpha-cell hormone.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The study reported herein was carried out by cooperation of the Departments of Agronomy and Animal Nutrition. The lignification study reported was conducted with three grasses, viz, Timothy, Brome and Reed Canary grass, while the digestibility study was conducted with Timothy only. A method of estimating the percentage of lignified area in plant tissue is described and has been used throughout the study. The percentage of lignified area in the stem increased as the plant matured. In Timothy and Brome grass the percentage of lignified area increased as one progressed up the culm. With Reed Canary grass the reverse was true in stages at which rapid growth was taking place. After rapid growth had ceased, the situation was found in Timothy and Brome grass. Feeding trials showed decreasing digestibility with increasing maturity. Study of ttie fecal slides indicated that all undigested plant tissue was lignified. The percentage of lignified area in the stem accounted for approximately 50% of the undigested Dry Matter of the feeding trial.
thesis.creator: Steppler, Howard A.
thesis.subject: Agronomy.
thesis.title: Lignification studies with various grass species.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Thulium, in the form of Tm203, has been made radioactive by neutron irradiation In a pile. The radiations have been investigated by a magnetic beta-spectrometer and by absorption methods. A conversion line is found at an energy of 0.0682 +/- .0011 Mev. and indicates a gamma ray of 0.129 +/- .003 Mev. The beta spectrum is found to be complex as the result of a Kurie plot with apparently three components whose end points are 0.953 +/- .020 Mev., O.526 +/- .020 Mev., and 0.30U +/- .020 Mev. The intensities are, respectively, 74%, 18%, and 8% as Judged by the graphical integration of the areas under the components. The existence of these components and the values of the end points are subject to confirmation by gamma ray and coincidence measurements. As the result of absorption measurements of the gamma rays in lead it is believed that the gamma radiation consists of three components with energies about 0.1 Mev., 0.2 Mev. and 0.8 Mev. respectively.[...]
thesis.creator: Newsham, Lloyd G.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: The disintegration of thulium.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This survey was undertaken in the hope of extending our knowledge of the Appalachian Mountain System and i t s erosional history by study of the topography of part of the System in Canada, The area studied lies chiefly in the Eastern Townships of Quebec, where the Appalachians cross with a northeasterly trend, south of the St.Lawrence River, and north of the United States border. This part of the Appalachians in Canada is, in the main, a continuation of the Green Mountains of Vermont and is known as the Notre Dame Mountains. The System also includes the Sutton and Megantic Mountains. The Topographic Survey of Canada has published contour maps of this region on a scale of one mile to one inch, with a contour interval of twenty-five feet. [...]
thesis.creator: Stalker, A. MacS.
thesis.subject: Geological Sciences.
thesis.title: A study of erosion surfaces in the southern part of the Eastern Townships of Quebec.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The experimental work which forms the basis of this discussion represents the first report of a long term investigation under the direction of Dr.Boris P. Babkin. It is a privilege to acknowledge his able and enthusiastic direction, his keen and logical criticism as well as his active participation in many of the experiments. We are grateful to Dr. Wilder Penfield for suggestions regarding the general course of the investigation and for the inspiration of his own work in man.[...]
thesis.creator: Speakman, T.J.
thesis.subject: Neurology.
thesis.title: Cortical localization of autonomic function.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This study was begun on the suggestion of two physicians in the Allergy Clinic at the ChildrenTs Memorial Hospital in Montreal. They had noted that, out of a group of about one hundred and twenty-five children whom they were treating, most responded well to treatment but a few responded poorly. All were receiving the same instructions and medications. The physicians believed that there might be social and/or emotional factors which hampered the response to treatment in certain cases. It was for this reason that they consulted the Social Service Department of the hospital in regard to a special review of these cases. This was the first opportunity for such co-operative work as the Social Service Department had been newly opened three months previously, after a lapse of five years.[...]
thesis.creator: Smith, Ruth M.
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: Social emotional factors in children with bronchial asthma.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This is a study of the morphology and systematics of the order Conularida, as currently restricted, that is to the genus Conularia as generally thought of until 1928., This order consists of animals of unknown nature, now represented in rocks-of Palaeozoic age by phosphatic tubes which were their coverings in life. At one time the Conularida included a wide variety of more or less tubular shells, but some of these have been shown to be worms, others to be pteropods, and all the calcareous forms, Kyolithes, Tentaculites, Styliolina &c., have been removed to other groups. [...]
thesis.creator: Sinclair, George Winston.
thesis.subject: Gastropoda, Fossil.
Paleobiology.
thesis.title: The biology of the Conularida.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It is well known that a number of microorganisms including bacteria and fungi are carried on and in seeds of barley and other cereals. Some of these organisms are known to be destructive parasites but most of them have been considered to be saprophytes and to a large extent ignored. Little is known concerning the role that they play either in relation to the development and behavior of the seed itself or to disease development caused by the parasites carried on the seed.
thesis.creator: Simard, Thomas.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Studies on the microflora of barley seed with special reference to helminthosporium sativum P. K. and B.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
